title: The Future of Attention Measurement in Digital Advertising
excerpt: How predictive eye-tracking is changing the way brands measure ad effectiveness and optimize their media spend.
content:
# The Future of Attention Measurement in Digital Advertising

The advertising industry is undergoing a fundamental transformation. For decades, marketers relied on proxy metrics like impressions, clicks, and viewability to gauge campaign performance. But these metrics tell us only part of the story—they reveal whether an ad had the opportunity to be seen, not whether it actually captured human attention.

## The Attention Economy

In an era of infinite content and finite attention, understanding what consumers actually look at has become the holy grail of advertising measurement. This is where attention metrics come in.

Attention measurement uses advanced eye-tracking technology—both panel-based studies and predictive AI models—to determine:

- **Whether an ad was actually seen** (not just served)
- **How long viewers looked at it** (dwell time)
- **Which elements captured the most attention** (creative analysis)
- **How attention correlates with brand outcomes** (effectiveness)

## Predictive Eye-Tracking: Scaling Attention Measurement

Traditional eye-tracking required expensive hardware and controlled lab environments. While incredibly accurate, this approach couldn't scale to measure real-world campaign performance.

Predictive eye-tracking changes everything. By training AI models on millions of real eye-tracking data points, we can now predict attention at scale—across every impression, every placement, every device.

## What This Means for Advertisers

For the first time, advertisers can:

1. **Optimize media buying** based on predicted attention, not just viewability
2. **Compare performance** across channels using a common attention currency
3. **Improve creative** by understanding what elements drive attention
4. **Reduce waste** by identifying low-attention placements before spending

The future of advertising isn't about reaching more people—it's about genuinely connecting with them. Attention measurement makes that possible.
author: Dr. Mike Follett

title: How a Leading CPG Brand Increased ROI by 40%
excerpt: Learn how attention metrics helped a major consumer goods company optimize their media spend across channels and dramatically improve campaign performance.
content:
# How a Leading CPG Brand Increased ROI by 40%

When one of the world's largest consumer packaged goods companies came to Lumen, they faced a common challenge: their digital advertising was generating impressions, but they couldn't tell if those impressions were actually driving results.

## The Challenge

The brand was spending over $50 million annually on digital advertising across:

- Programmatic display
- Social media (Facebook, Instagram, TikTok)
- Connected TV
- YouTube pre-roll

Despite sophisticated attribution modeling, they struggled to understand why some campaigns significantly outperformed others. Viewability scores were consistently high (85%+), but brand lift and sales impact varied wildly.

## The Approach

We implemented a comprehensive attention measurement program:

### Phase 1: Attention Audit
We measured attention across all active campaigns to establish baselines. The results were eye-opening—viewability and attention told very different stories.

### Phase 2: Attention Optimization
Using these insights, we worked with their media team to:

- Reallocate budget toward high-attention placements
- Eliminate consistently low-attention inventory
- Optimize creative based on attention patterns

### Phase 3: Attention Bidding
We implemented real-time attention bidding, allowing their DSP to optimize toward predicted attention rather than just viewability.

## The Results

After 6 months:

- **40% increase in brand lift** at equal spend
- **25% reduction in cost-per-attention-second**
- **3x improvement in attention quality** on programmatic

> "For the first time, we could see what consumers actually saw. The attention data transformed how we think about media investment." — VP of Media, CPG Brand

## Key Takeaways

1. Viewability ≠ Attention. High viewability doesn't guarantee high attention.
2. Attention predicts outcomes better than traditional metrics.
3. Real-time optimization on attention can dramatically improve ROI.

content:
# 2025 Attention Benchmarks Report Now Available

We're excited to announce the release of our 2025 Attention Benchmarks Report—the industry's most comprehensive study of advertising attention across channels, formats, and industries.

## What's Inside

This year's report analyzes attention data from over **10 billion impressions** across:

### Channels Covered
- Digital display (desktop & mobile)
- Video (in-stream, out-stream, social)
- Connected TV
- Social media (all major platforms)
- Digital out-of-home

### Key Metrics
- **Attention Rate**: Percentage of impressions that receive any attention
- **Average Attention Time**: Mean dwell time when attention occurs
- **Attention Quality Score**: Composite metric combining rate and time
- **Brand Attention**: Time specifically on brand elements

## Headline Findings

### 1. CTV Dominates Attention Quality
Connected TV continues to deliver the highest attention quality scores, with average attention times 4x higher than digital display.

### 2. Mobile vs. Desktop Gap Narrows
Mobile attention has improved significantly, with the attention gap between mobile and desktop shrinking to just 15% (down from 35% in 2023).

### 3. Short-Form Video Surprises
6-second video ads on social platforms now outperform 15-second spots on attention efficiency metrics.

### 4. Industry Variations
Financial services and automotive see 2x the attention rates of FMCG—but creative quality matters more than category.

## How to Use These Benchmarks

The report includes:

- **Planning tools** to set realistic attention targets
- **Optimization frameworks** for improving underperforming campaigns
- **Creative guidelines** based on high-attention executions
- **Channel comparison matrices** for media mix decisions

## Download the Report

Lumen clients can access the full report in the LAMP platform. New to Lumen? Contact us to request a copy and schedule a benchmarks review session.

---

*The 2025 Attention Benchmarks Report is based on attention measurement data from Q1-Q4 2024, covering campaigns across 20+ countries and 15 industry verticals.*

title: Why Viewability Is Not Enough: The Case for Attention Metrics
excerpt: Viewability was a crucial first step, but it's time to evolve beyond opportunity-to-see to actual attention measurement.
content:
# Why Viewability Is Not Enough: The Case for Attention Metrics

Viewability revolutionized digital advertising when it was introduced. For the first time, advertisers could ensure their ads had the *opportunity* to be seen. But opportunity is not the same as attention.

## The Viewability Standard

The MRC viewability standard requires:

- **Display ads**: 50% of pixels in view for 1 second
- **Video ads**: 50% of pixels in view for 2 continuous seconds

These thresholds were designed as a baseline—a minimum viable exposure. They were never meant to indicate that an ad was actually *seen* or *processed* by a human.

## The Attention Gap

Our research consistently shows that viewable does not equal viewed:

- Only **35%** of viewable display ads receive any human attention
- Average attention time on "viewable" ads is just **0.9 seconds**
- **42%** of video ads meeting viewability standards are never watched

## Why the Gap Exists

### Banner Blindness
Users have learned to ignore areas of the screen typically occupied by ads. An ad can be technically viewable while being completely invisible to the user.

### Scroll Behavior
Viewability is measured the moment an ad enters the viewport. Users often scroll past before attention can shift to the ad.

### Multitasking
Just because a tab is active doesn't mean the user is looking at it. They might be on another device or looking away from the screen.

## The Solution: Attention Metrics

Attention metrics tell you what viewability cannot:

| Metric | Viewability | Attention |
|--------|-------------|------------|
| What it measures | Opportunity to see | Actual eyes on ad |
| Correlation with outcomes | Moderate | Strong |
| Creative insights | None | Detailed |
| True media quality | Partial | Complete |

## Moving Forward

Viewability isn't going away—it remains a useful filter. But leading advertisers are adding attention as a layer on top of viewability to understand true campaign performance.

The question isn't "Was my ad viewable?" It's "Did anyone actually look at it?"

---

*Want to see the attention performance of your current campaigns? Contact us for a free attention audit.*
author: Dr. Mike Follett
